description: From on- +‎ look. Compare Old English onlēċ (“onlook, consideration, regard”).

entries.meaning: The act of looking on (something); observation.
examples: The object of the onlook is taken to be more than physical, more than just sense-experience, therefore it is meta-physical.

entries.meaning: That which is looked at, regarded, or considered.

examples: This onlook is certainly foundational to Christianity.  […]  Religious belief is the conviction (or hope) that one's onlook conforms to an authoritative onlook, a divine onlook.

description: From on- +‎ look. Compare Old English onlōcian.

verbs.description: onlook (third-person singular simple present onlooks, present participle onlooking, simple past and past participle onlooked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To look on or look at; watch; observe; view; regard.
examples: So they two fought for so long a time that those who onlooked were astonished at the strength and the courage and the endurance of those two champions,  […]
